title: Amrit Mangat
text:
Amrit Mangat (born ) is a former politician in <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a>, Canada. She was a <a href="Ontario%20Liberal%20Party">Liberal</a> member of the <a href="Legislative%20Assembly%20of%20Ontario">Legislative Assembly of Ontario</a> from 2007 to 2018 who represented the <a href="electoral%20district%20%28Canada%29">riding</a> of <a href="Mississauga%E2%80%94Brampton%20South%20%28provincial%20electoral%20district%29">Mississauga—Brampton South</a>.
Background.
Mangat was born in Jagroan, India. Her parents were originally from <a href="West%20Punjab">West Punjab</a> but were forced to emigrate during the <a href="Partition%20of%20India%20in%201947">Partition of India in 1947</a>. Mangat studied in India and obtained degrees in political science, economics, English and education. After immigrating to Canada in 1992 she obtained her <a href="Ontario%20College%20of%20Teachers">Ontario College of Teachers</a> certification. In addition to teaching, Mangat managed several small businesses. She most recently worked as an administrator in a law firm, helping new Canadians to settle.
She lives with her husband Jaswant who works as a lawyer.
Politics.
In 2004 she tried to get nominated in the federal riding of <a href="Brampton%20West">Brampton West</a> but lost to <a href="Colleen%20Beaumier">Colleen Beaumier</a>. In the <a href="2007%20Ontario%20general%20election">2007 provincial election</a> she ran as the <a href="Ontario%20Liberal%20Party">Liberal</a> candidate in the riding of <a href="Mississauga%E2%80%94Brampton%20South%20%28provincial%20electoral%20district%29">Mississauga—Brampton South</a>. During the campaign she came out in support of keeping <a href="Peel%20Memorial%20Hospital">Peel Memorial Hospital</a> open and she spoke against the Conservative promise to fund private faith-based schools. She defeated <a href="Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20Ontario">Progressive Conservative</a> candidate Ravi Singh by 10,405 votes. She was re-elected in <a href="2011%20Ontario%20general%20election">2011</a> and <a href="2014%20Ontario%20general%20election">2014</a>.
During her time in government she was appointed as <a href="Parliamentary%20assistant">Parliamentary assistant</a> to a number of roles including Seniors and transportation.
As of 2014, she serves as a Parliamentary Assistant to the <a href="Ministry%20of%20the%20Environment%20%28Ontario%29">Minister of the Environment and Climate Change</a>.
In the 2018 Provincial Election, she stood in the new riding of <a href="Mississauga%E2%80%94Malton%20%28provincial%20electoral%20district%29">Mississauga—Malton</a> and placed third.
